articles.headline: Court Decisions on Voting Rules Sow Confusion in State Races
articles.snippet: With the midterm elections weeks away, the rulings over laws that Republican-led state governments passed to more tightly regulate voting are changing procedures and could affect outcomes in some states.
articles.abstract: With the midterm elections weeks away, the rulings over laws that Republican-led state governments passed to more tightly regulate voting are changing procedures and could affect outcomes in some states.
articles.lead_paragraph: NILES, Ohio — Just weeks before elections that will decide control of the Senate and crucial governors’ races, a cascade of court rulings about voting rules, issued by judges with an increasingly partisan edge, are sowing confusion and changing voting procedures with the potential to affect outcomes in some states.

articles.headline: Why Aid for College Is Missing the Mark
articles.snippet: The government strategy to subsidize higher education is failing at its core task: giving less privileged Americans a real shot at a college degree.
articles.abstract: The government strategy to subsidize higher education is failing at its core task: giving less privileged Americans a real shot at a college degree.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 1987, when he was Ronald Reagan’s education secretary, the conservative culture warrior William J. Bennett wrote a famous essay denouncing federal aid for higher education because it allowed colleges “blithely to raise their tuitions,” at little benefit to students.

articles.headline: In the U.S., a Turning Point in the Flow of Oil
articles.snippet: Thanks to new techniques, an oil bounty is likely to make the United States a major exporter of oil again. Not everyone is cheering.
articles.abstract: Thanks to new techniques, an oil bounty is likely to make the United States a major exporter of oil again. Not everyone is cheering.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The Singapore-flagged tanker BW Zambesi set sail with little fanfare from the port of Galveston, Tex., on July 30, loaded with crude oil destined for South Korea. But though it left inauspiciously, the ship’s launch was another critical turning point in what has been a half-decade of tectonic change for the American oil industry.

articles.headline: Profit at Goldman Less Easy to Find
articles.snippet: Recent regulations hit hardest on the very businesses, like trading, where Goldman Sachs makes the most money.
articles.abstract: Recent regulations hit hardest on the very businesses, like trading, where Goldman Sachs makes the most money.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even when Goldman Sachs’s public reputation was taking a beating, the bank’s business acumen and profit remained the envy of Wall Street.

articles.headline: Health Law Drug Plans Are Given a Check-Up
articles.snippet: Early studies of prescription drug use by people buying health insurance through health exchanges suggest that they are often sicker than those insured by employers.
articles.abstract: Early studies of prescription drug use by people buying health insurance through health exchanges suggest that they are often sicker than those insured by employers.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the new health insurance exchanges opened for business one year ago, whether they would succeed was a matter of fervent debate. Who would sign up? Would they know how to use their insurance? And would a flood of seriously ill patients overwhelm insurers, sending premiums skyrocketing and dooming the new law?

articles.headline: In This Election, Obama’s Party Benches Him
articles.snippet: Democratic candidates — even those in states like Virginia that the president carried in 2008 and 2012 — do not want President Obama to campaign for them.
articles.abstract: Democratic candidates — even those in states like Virginia that the president carried in 2008 and 2012 — do not want President Obama to campaign for them.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — When he soared to victory by almost 10 million votes in 2008, President Obama won in states like Virginia that Democratic candidates had not captured since 1964. He was trumpeted as a transformational leader who remade American politics by creating a new electoral map and a diverse voter coalition to shape the Democratic Party for the 21st century.

articles.headline: Life, Death and Grim Routine Fill the Day at a Liberian Ebola Clinic
articles.snippet: Health workers tend to people sickened by Ebola and those quarantined while they wait to learn if they have the virus.
articles.abstract: Health workers tend to people sickened by Ebola and those quarantined while they wait to learn if they have the virus.
articles.lead_paragraph: SUAKOKO, Liberia — The dirt road winds and dips, passes through a rubber plantation and arrives up a hill, near the grounds of an old leper colony. The latest scourge, Ebola, is under assault here in a cluster of cobalt-blue buildings operated by an American charity, International Medical Corps. In the newly opened treatment center, Liberian workers and volunteers from abroad identify who is infected, save those they can and try to halt the virus’s spread.

articles.headline: To Lure Young Readers, Nonfiction Writers Sanitize and Simplify
articles.snippet: Inspired by the booming market for young adult novels, a growing number of biographers and historians are retrofitting their works to make them palatable for younger readers.
articles.abstract: Inspired by the booming market for young adult novels, a growing number of biographers and historians are retrofitting their works to make them palatable for younger readers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Of all the horrors Louis Zamperini endured during World War II — a plane crash into the Pacific, 47 days stranded at sea, two years in a prisoner-of-war camp — the one experience that truly haunted him was when a Japanese guard tortured and killed an injured duck.

articles.headline: Death of Thomas Eric Duncan in Dallas Fuels Alarm Over Ebola
articles.snippet: Mr. Duncan’s death renewed questions about health officials’ preparedness to contain Ebola. Hours after, hospital officials said a second patient had been admitted in Dallas.
articles.abstract: Mr. Duncan’s death renewed questions about health officials’ preparedness to contain Ebola. Hours after, hospital officials said a second patient had been admitted in Dallas.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS — For Louise Troh, word of the death of her fiancé, Thomas Eric Duncan, unfolded Wednesday as everything else has since he was found to have Ebola — at a distance.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez and Dave Philipps
